raw_text: First, it has been shown that Model 4 produces a very good alignment quality in comparison to various other alignment models (Och and Ney, 2000b)
clean_text: First, it has been shown that Model 4 produces a very good alignment quality in comparison to various other alignment models (Och and Ney, 2000b).

Alternative measures for the evaluation of one-to-one word links have been proposed in (Och and Ney, 2000a; Och and Ney, 2003)
clean_text: Alternative measures for the evaluation of one-to-one word links have been proposed in (Och and Ney, 2000a; Och and Ney, 2003).

raw_text: Our gold standards include random samples from the corpus instead (Ahrenberg et al, 2000) .Furthermore, we do not split MWU links as pro posed by (Och and Ney, 2000a)
clean_text: Furthermore, we do not split MWU links as proposed by (Och and Ney, 2000a).

raw_text: As in other uses of parallel corpora, good alignment is essential in order for the results to be meaningful (Och and Ney, 2000)
clean_text: As in other uses of parallel corpora, good alignment is essential in order for the results to be meaningful (Och and Ney, 2000).

raw_text: Clearly we would benefit from better matching and alignment techniques, and we wonder if perhaps some of the alignment techniques used for parallel multi-lingual corpora (Och and Ney, 2000) could be adapted to help align our text-data corpora
clean_text: Clearly we would benefit from better matching and alignment techniques, and we wonder if perhaps some of the alignment techniques used for parallel multi-lingual corpora (Och and Ney, 2000) could be adapted to help align our text-data corpora.

raw_text: We know that better alignment models have been proposed and extensively compared (Och and Ney, 2000)
clean_text: We know that better alignment models have been proposed and extensively compared (Och and Ney, 2000).

citing_paper_authors: Cyril, Goutte | Kenji, Yamada | Eric, Gaussier
raw_text: The data is from the Canadian Hansard, and reference alignments were originally produced by Franz Och and Hermann Ney (Och and Ney, 2000)
clean_text: The data is from the Canadian Hansard, and reference alignments were originally produced by Franz Och and Hermann Ney (Och and Ney, 2000).

raw_text: Recent statistical machine translation (SMT) algorithms generate such a translation by incorporating an inventory of bilingual phrases (OchandNey, 2000)
clean_text: Recent statistical machine translation (SMT) algorithms generate such a translation by incorporating an inventory of bilingual phrases (Och and Ney, 2000).

raw_text: Word alignment using GIZA++ toolkit (Och and Ney, 2000), the default configuration as available intraining scripts for Moses
clean_text: Word alignment using GIZA++ toolkit (Och and Ney, 2000), the default configuration as available in training scripts for Moses.

raw_text: The classical approaches to word alignment are based on IBM models 1-5 (Brown et al, 1994) and the HMM based alignment model (Vogel et al, 1996) (Och and Ney, 2000a, 2000b), while recently discriminative approaches (Moore, 2006) and syntax based approaches (Zhang and Gildea, 2005) for word alignment are also studied
clean_text: The classical approaches to word alignment are based on IBM models 1-5 (Brown et al, 1994) and the HMM based alignment model (Vogel et al, 1996) (Och and Ney, 2000a, 2000b), while recently discriminative approaches (Moore, 2006) and syntax based approaches (Zhang and Gildea, 2005) for word alignment are also studied.

raw_text: In this paper, we present improvements to the HMM based alignment model originally proposed by (Vogel et al., 1996, Och and Ney, 2000a)
clean_text: In this paper, we present improvements to the HMM based alignment model originally proposed by (Vogel et al., 1996, Och and Ney, 2000a).

raw_text: In order to improve transition models in the HMM based alignment, Och and Ney (2000a) extended the transition models to be word-class dependent
clean_text: In order to improve transition models in the HMM based alignment, Och and Ney (2000a) extended the transition models to be word-class dependent.

raw_text: In the next section we briefly review modeling of transition probabilities in a conventional HMM alignment model (Vogel et al, 1996, Och and Ney, 2000a)
clean_text: In the next section we briefly review modeling of transition probabilities in a conventional HMM alignment model (Vogel et al, 1996, Och and Ney, 2000a).

raw_text: We briefly review the HMM based word alignment models (Vogel, 1996, Och and Ney, 2000a)
clean_text: We briefly review the HMM based word alignment models (Vogel, 1996, Och and Ney, 2000a).

raw_text: In (Och and Ney, 2000a), the word null is introduced to generate the French words that don ' t align to any English words
clean_text: In (Och and Ney, 2000a), the word null is introduced to generate the French words that don ' t align to any English words.

raw_text: Tests sentence pairs were manually aligned and were marked with both sure and possible alignments (Och and Ney 2000a)
clean_text: Tests sentence pairs were manually aligned and were marked with both sure and possible alignments (Och and Ney 2000a).
